repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: \_\_cinit__ is used to get objects into a correct and safe state. Otherwise, the regular \_\_init__ is sufficient and more flexible.

comment_data.body:
I disagree with this change I think. In typical use it'll create and destroy a pointless rectangle.

I definitely get the point of preferring `__init__` but in cases like this where `__cinit__` is the right choice, I don't see the point in also providing `__init__`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,7 +5,12 @@ from Rectangle cimport Rectangle
 cdef class PyRectangle:
     cdef Rectangle*c_rect  # hold a pointer to the C++ instance which we're wrapping
 
-    def __cinit__(self, int x0, int y0, int x1, int y1):
+    def __cinit__(self):
+        self.c_rect = new Rectangle()
+
+    def __init__(self, int x0, int y0, int x1, int y1):

comment_data.body: The problem is that, what if later on, the programmer wants to inherit from PyRectangle and create a PySquare that only take in x0, x1, and width as parameters. Using \_\_cinit__ would prevent that possibility. Perhaps, instead of creating a new rectangle, I will just change the attributes of the existing rectangle.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,7 +5,12 @@ from Rectangle cimport Rectangle
 cdef class PyRectangle:
     cdef Rectangle*c_rect  # hold a pointer to the C++ instance which we're wrapping
 
-    def __cinit__(self, int x0, int y0, int x1, int y1):
+    def __cinit__(self):
+        self.c_rect = new Rectangle()
+
+    def __init__(self, int x0, int y0, int x1, int y1):

comment_data.body:
> inherit from PyRectangle and create a PySquare

That's a bad design because it violates the Liskov Substitution Principle. :-)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,7 +5,12 @@ from Rectangle cimport Rectangle
 cdef class PyRectangle:
     cdef Rectangle*c_rect  # hold a pointer to the C++ instance which we're wrapping
 
-    def __cinit__(self, int x0, int y0, int x1, int y1):
+    def __cinit__(self):
+        self.c_rect = new Rectangle()
+
+    def __init__(self, int x0, int y0, int x1, int y1):

comment_data.body: Rather, I could imagine allowing `*args`  and `**kwargs` in `__cinit__` to accommodate for subclasses.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,7 +5,12 @@ from Rectangle cimport Rectangle
 cdef class PyRectangle:
     cdef Rectangle*c_rect  # hold a pointer to the C++ instance which we're wrapping
 
-    def __cinit__(self, int x0, int y0, int x1, int y1):
+    def __cinit__(self):
+        self.c_rect = new Rectangle()
+
+    def __init__(self, int x0, int y0, int x1, int y1):

comment_data.body: Given that there are no arguments, I think `__cinit__` is fine here. It prevents the attribute from being `None` early on.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -284,7 +284,7 @@ when it is deleted.::
 
         cdef object cheeses
 
-        def __cinit__(self):
+        def __init__(self):

comment_data.body: However, the way it's structured now is a very good example: Safe initialisation in a bare `__cinit__`, proper value setting in `__init__`, controllable by subclasses. Let's keep it that way.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,7 +5,12 @@ from Rectangle cimport Rectangle
 cdef class PyRectangle:
     cdef Rectangle*c_rect  # hold a pointer to the C++ instance which we're wrapping
 
-    def __cinit__(self, int x0, int y0, int x1, int y1):
+    def __cinit__(self):
+        self.c_rect = new Rectangle()
+
+    def __init__(self, int x0, int y0, int x1, int y1):

comment_data.body: Using `__init__` allows Cython to automatically generate the `__reduce__` method for pickling and copying the object. If the attribute was an extension type, then None could be unsafe (since nonecheck=False by default). But in this case, the code is still memory safe since the attribute is typed as an object,
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -284,7 +284,7 @@ when it is deleted.::
 
         cdef object cheeses
 
-        def __cinit__(self):
+        def __init__(self):

comment_data.body: @scoder Do you still want me to change it back? I am not sure if you read my last comment.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -284,7 +284,7 @@ when it is deleted.::
 
         cdef object cheeses
 
-        def __cinit__(self):
+        def __init__(self):

comment_data.body:
Looking at the full example I think `cheeses` should be typed as `list`, and the initializer kept as `__cinit__`.

Clearly it's not a completely definitive "this is the right way to write it". But that's probably how I'd write it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -284,7 +284,7 @@ when it is deleted.::
 
         cdef object cheeses
 
-        def __cinit__(self):
+        def __init__(self):

comment_data.body: Okay, then. Well it looks like the master branch moved ahead of me. I have deleted my change to this example, so merging this PR will not change the current example on master (which has `cheeses` typed as `object`, and keeps `__cinit__`). @da-woods Would you like me to change `cheeses` to be typed as `list`? Doing so will require rebasing.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -284,7 +284,7 @@ when it is deleted.::
 
         cdef object cheeses
 
-        def __cinit__(self):
+        def __init__(self):

comment_data.body:
I think we should just merge this now with the examples we all agree on. We don't have to change everything here - it's not like using cinit is wrong.

I'll do that when the tests have all finished
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -284,7 +284,7 @@ when it is deleted.::
 
         cdef object cheeses
 
-        def __cinit__(self):
+        def __init__(self):

commit.message: Replace unnecessary __cinit__ with __init__ in documentation examples
Use __cinit__ when necessary in the wrapping C++ examples
Modify existing Rectangle instead of creating a new Rectangle in the pointer to Rectangle example

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Replace cinit doc examples
